feed.title: Review: Soulcalibur V
feed.subtitle: Soulcalibur V has a great look and style, but more story is needed according to Paul Chapman.

link.Abstract: Soulcalibur V has great visuals, but needs more character depth, according to The Province's game reviewer Paul Chapman.
link.title: Soulcalibur V

link.Abstract: Developed by Bandi-Namco’s internal Project Soul team, the latest entry in the tournament-style fighting series takes place 17 years after the events of the previous game. In Soulcalibur V, Patroklos, the son of the divine fighter Sophita locates his long lost sister Pyrrha. Together, they must battle various challengers in order to gain possession of the pure Soulcalibur sword, the only thing that can stop a new and more powerful incarnation of Nightmare from consuming the world.

category.term: 317~Mortal Kombat~Microsoft Xbox 360~Sony PlayStation3~Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
Nostalgia goes a long way with most entertainment categories.

What was once loved before, then considered passe, almost always carries a sweet sense of romanticism that welcomes some form of resurrection in the future.

The gaming world experienced that last year with the rebirth of Mortal Kombat. The formerly tired fighting game genre was brought back to life by some updates, some clever additions and the advent of online play.

Now we have the release of Soulcalibur V for Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3. This is a curious application of the “retro” tag, because Soulcalibur has never really gone away.

And while it’s critically lauded for everything from graphics to the game mechanics, it’s never hit the sales marks, or cultural relevance that a game like Mortal Kombat has.

So, let’s start with the good.

If Mortal Kombat was the king of all fighting games, and Street Fighter not far behind, the third on the rung was always Tekken. Game developer Namco was responsible for that, and they brought the same visual hallmarks that made Tekken so popular to Soulcalibur. As it was a flagship game on the old Sega DreamCast system -- and that system was hailing the best graphics in gaming -- Soulcalibur has always done a brilliant job with the look of this game.

Detailed, moody, expansive backgrounds that feature small pieces that catch your eye, realistic fighters with rich outfits and smooth, fluid moves that while otherworldly, do look realistic.

The difference with Soulcalibur was always the weaponry. Yes, the other fighting games had fireballs and the occasional foreign object, but for the most part it was fists, feet and throws that did the damage.

Soulcalibur was always about swordplay and more ancient, and mystical fighting.

This game has stayed true to those roots, has upped the ante in terms of look and graphics, and also in the weaponry division.

The characters are mostly classic, with some newer, younger characters. They do all carry a story, but don’t play it up nearly as well as MK or its fighting sibling Tekken.

This is an issue for me. I should add, many fighting game lovers play to invent or execute huge combos, stringing moves together to create the unstoppable attack. For me, it’s all about the story. The only reason for me to play through fighting games more than once is to find out more about characters.

Soulcalibur V isn’t great in that respect.

They have added a story mode as well as the standard arcade mode, but it’s not executed anywhere near as well as last year’s Mortal Kombat. There are some cut scenes and some explanation but the only reason to really stick with this mode is to unlock some new characters and extras, not necessarily to find out more details about the game’s characters.

The fighting mechanics are great though. You can pull together some impressive combos, there are all sorts of strategy elements in play, including the Brave Edge meter that you have to fill, and then use to boost your attacks, to the guard impact for your defence, and the critical gauge that will help execute special attacks.

Involved in that are special attacks that use other objects, like glowing energy orbs or even calling in mystical creatures to help attack your foe from all angles.

If you’re into fighting games, then you’ll really love this, as it’s a technical game with loads of strategy and untold options in how to use attacks.

The problem for me is that there’s not enough to string the gameplay together. If a fighting game is going to hold my attention and have me play for more than a couple of hours, I need a bit more to the story and more depth to the characters. I want to know why my character needs to win the battle, not be entranced with chaining 47 button commands together.

The online play is good, as they do have lobbies to find matches, and impressively a spectator mode so you can watch other players battle if you’re in to that sort of thing.

It does add to the value of the game, and as human opposition is way different than the Artificial Intelligence, it provides a different level of challenge.

Rating: M for Mature, gore and violence.

What’s right: Look, style, fluid nature of the game, great weapons.

What’s wrong: Story mode is a dud.

Numb Thumb: graphics A+; gameplay C+; Value C+; Control B. Overall a B on Numb Thumb.

Modern Warfare

When word leaked of a potential “subscription” to play Call of Duty games online the gaming community lit up like a jeep that was hit by an RPG. That didn’t happen, but it’s clear that the future of gaming, even with full retail pricing, will be added content and features for more money.

It’s curious that you can pay under $5 for a game like Angry Birds and free fresh content is still added to it a year later, but the idea with games like Gears of War 3 or Modern Warfare 3 is that for new “chapters” or extra multiplayer options you’ll have to shell out. Gears 3 of course had the Season’s Pass that saw an extra “prequel” chapter of gameplay in campaign style along with more arenas and maps online in multiplayer.

Modern Warfare 3 has its Elite subscription and what has been made available for Xbox 360 owners has now been announced for PlayStation 3 owners as well.

You’ll get two new maps, Piazza and Liberation on February 28.

The maps feature a battle in Central Park, with mounted turrets and lots of sniper points, and a seaside town with lots of blind corners and open corridors. The Elite package costs $50 and promises to be releasing new content all the way into October of 2012.

pchapman@theprovince.com

twitter.com/paulc14

link.Abstract: This year gamers of all platforms, with perhaps the overall exception of the Wii, got more games than they had time to play. From countless sequels to original offerings, there was no shortage of fun, or Game of the Year contenders to be had. Join WatchMojo.com as we list the games that thrilled and entertained us in 2011.
